1  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Western Precooling Systems?Yuma Shop (WPS?Yuma Shop) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply not to have accidental releases or emergencies.  The company endeavors to execute these policies through the implementation of its Safety Program.  The company safety program includes, but is not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM).  PSM is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases.  It is the primary goal of WPS to protect employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to company operations. 

WPS has adopted a ?non-responding facility? policy; has an established Emergency Action Plan and has taken the steps necessary to be included in the community emergency plan.  An Emergency Coordinator has been established and coordination with the State Emergency Response Commission (SERC), Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Fire Department is performed on an ongoing basis.  Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated and kept current through the annual submission of appropriate Reports and periodic tours of the facility by the Fire Department.  

WPS policy also includes maintaining appropriate emergency capabilities and to deal with emergencies safely if and when they do happen.  Key WPS employees attend 1910.120 (q) Emergency Response training that is refreshed annually.  Emergency equipment is maintained under the control of WPS.  The company strives to execute its emergency response policies through skilled employees that are provided with adequate and appropriate equipment and training.

1.2  General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The WPS-Yuma Shop was previously known as Central Refrigeration Services, Inc. which is 100% owned by WPS.  The WPS-Yuma Shop is an ammonia refrigeration service center owned and operated by WPS.  WPS provides ammonia refrigeration ser

vices and equipment to many of the seasonally operated coolers in the area. Two ammonia storage vessels are used for temporary seasonal storage of ammonia.  The first of the two storage vessels was placed on-site in 1988.  The second vessel was acquired in 1994.

Access to the tanks is limited by fenced enclosure of the property.  The tanks are in a protected area, covered with shade to minimize the exposure to radiant heat from sunlight.  Traffic barriers are in place to discourage vehicle traffic at the tanks.  In 1997 a water system was installed to help cool the tanks on extremely hot days (120 degrees F+) which provides effective evaporative cooling of the tank skin which reduces the pressure in the vessel.

Produce growing and shipping is a seasonal event in Yuma.  Typically the fresh vegetables come into season in early November and finish in April.  When cooling equipment is taken out of service in the spring the refrigerant is transferred out of that equipment and stored in the vessels at Yuma Shop.  The storage vessels are rated at a higher pressure than the nominal refrigeration systems that the refrigerant is drawn from.  The vessels are rated for ammonia service, and are equipped with isolation and Pressure Relief Valves installed in accordance with applicable codes. The only Regulated Substance stored is anhydrous ammonia (NH3).  
 
1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Accidental Release Prevention Program

A comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM) has been established for the site, in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and processes.  PSM is an integral part of the Storage Facility operation.  The facility does not qualify for the PSM Program (>10,000 lbs NH3) during the busy season, which lasts from Fall until Spring (approximately 9-10 months).  At that time the ammonia is being used i

n off-site equipment. Storage in excess of 10,000 pounds lasts approximately 3-4 months (Summer).  The written PSM document is maintained in the site RMP binder.

WPS actively encourages its ammonia technicians to seek Certification through the Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).    

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Access to the tanks is limited by fenced enclosure of the property.  The tanks are in a protected area, covered with shade to minimize the exposure to radiant heat from sunlight.  Traffic barriers are in place to discourage vehicle traffic at the tanks.  In 1997 a water system was installed to help cool the tanks on extremely hot days (120 degrees F+) which provides effective evaporative cooling of the tank skin which reduces the pressure in the vessel.  Pressure Relief Valves are installed on the vessels per the applicable codes.

Maintenance is performed on the vessels while they are empty.  New pressure relief valves are scheduled for installation every 5 years per industry standards.   A vapor compressor and 4-way valve system provides the means to transfer refrigerant to / from the vessels.  The compressor and hose system is inspected for damage and wear and tear regularly.  Locked storage for transfer hoses was added 1/2004.

?Staff is trained in the benefits of good housekeeping.  The general appearance of the facility is maintained on a day-to-day basis.
